Imports from countries with which there were no bilateral arrangements could be subject to antidumping actions if sold at prices below basic import prices set by the EC. The EC's surveillance of steel and steel products imports introduced in 1981 was extended un t il Decem- ber 31, 1982. New basic import prices for these products provided for increases from January 1, 1982 averaging 7 percent for bulk steel products, 10 percent for special steel, and 5.5 percent for pig iron and ferromanganese. The United Kingdom imposed restrictions on imports of certain iron and steel products from Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia that were previously covered by voluntary restraint arrangements; quotas on certain textile goods from the People's Republic of China and Macao were also imposed. After the expiration of the bilateral agreement with the People's Republic of China in December 1982, the United States introduced unila- teral quantitative restrictions in January 1983, limiting imports of certain textile and apparel items from that country, to be in effect during negotia- tions of a new bilateral agreement with the People's Republic of China. In the United States, pressure to limit foreign competition perceived as unfa ir by domestic producers intensified. In June 1982 the U .S. Department of Commerce reached a prelimi- nary decision to levy offsetting penalties on steel imports from nine countries, including seven EC countries. Agreement was reached on October 21, 1982 between the United States and the EC to limit the EC's exports of ten categories of steel to the United States until the end of 1985 to 5 .12 percent of the U .S. market, in exchange for the withdrawal of the trade complaints by the U .S. steel industry. Trade frictions in the specialty steel sector also persisted. Investigations on five specialty steel products (stainless steel bar, rod, plate, sheets, and strip and alloy tool steel) that had been initiated in February and August 1982 have not yet been concluded, except for investigations of imports from Brazil, which did not result in quantitative restrictions. Simultaneously, the United States initi- ated discussions with trading partners aimed at the elimination of all trade distorting practices in the specialty steel sector and started to monitor imports of specialty steel products. International trade of automobiles continued to be highly regulated in 1982. Japan agreed in April to extend for a second year its restraint agreement with the United States, by which shipments of passenger cars into the United States would be limited to the level (1.68 million un i ts) agreed for the period April 1981-March 1982. In February 1983, Japan agreed to continue to restrain auto- mobile imports into the United States at 1.68 million units for a third year starting April 1, 1983. A similar agreement was concluded in May between Canada and Japan by which shipments of passenger cars into Canada for the period April 1- December 31, 1982 would be limited to 120,000 units, some 20,000 units less than in the compara- ble period in 1981. Restrictions on imports of items other than textiles, steel, and automobiles were introduced by several industrial countries. Canada introduced a global quota on imports of leather footwear for the period July 9, 1982 to November 30, 1984. This action was taken pursuant to Article XIX of the GATT on the basis of a finding by the Canadian Antidumping Tribunal that increased imports of footwear were causing or threatening serious injury to Canadian footwear producers. Shoes and boots of higher unit values were excluded at the end of 1982 from the global quota. A three-year joint discipline arrangement between the EC and Austria on mutual trade in cheeses entered into force on January 1, 1982. The EC also concluded agree- ments with Brazil, Indonesia, and Thailand, lim- iting imports of manioc from these countries. In February 1983, Japan informed the EC that its exports to the EC of videotape recorders and large color television tubes would not exceed 4.55 million units and 900,000 units, respectively, in 1983, and that it would exercise restraint on shipments of certain machine tools, automobiles, and color television sets, and would consult, if necessary, on shipments of light commercial vehi- cles, forklift trucks, motorcycles, color television sets, audio equipment, and quartz watches to the EC. France excluded various items from EC treat- ment (which permits free circulation of imported goods inside the Community once they have entered any member country) for a limited period. These items included radio receivers, umbrellas and sunshades, and quartz watches from Hong Kong, tents from the Republic of Korea, color television sets from Japan, and toys from Japan, Hong Kong, and the Republic of Korea. In addition, the impor- tation of Italian wines for the French market and various textile and wood goods from Turkey were suspended temporarily. In addition, customs for- malities for the importation of videotape recorders were localized at the customs office of Poitiers during October 1982-April 1983. France in Octo- ber also increased controls on commercial practices and revised customs procedures and in December instituted special hygienic controls for imports of 23 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS animal-based food products. The United Kingdom and several other countries in April prohibited importation of goods from Argentina. In February the United States extended through February 1984 quantitative limitations on the importation of clothespins, and in March crude oil imports from the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya were banned on grounds of national security. In May the United States imposed quotas and raised fees on imports of certain sugars, syrups, and molasses because these imports interfered with the operation of the do- mestic sugar price support program. As a means of avoiding the imposition of formal import quotas, the United States concluded restraint agreements on meat with Australia, Canada, and New Zealand until the end of 1983. Among the industrial countries, only Japan con- tinued to make progress in further opening its domestic market. In January 1982 the Government announced a package of measures to further ease and simplify import testing and other import proce- dures in order to improve access for foreign goods to the domestic market. The package included the improvement of 67 import-related measures on a wide range of products, including motor vehicles, cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, electric appliances, farm implements, sporting goods, chemicals, and food additives. In May 1982 and again in January 1983 the Government announced other trade liberalization packages, which included increased import quotas for agricultural products, an increase in the number of outlets available for the handling of tobacco products, acceptance of foreign testing results, clearer and more specific standards for imports, and simplification of import-testing procedures. Developments in the international oil market and the emergence of balance of payments difficulties led to the introduction and intensification of im- port restrictions in several oil-exporting countries. Algeria alone eased quantitative restrictions, allowing without authorization and up to a certain amount, imports for repair and maintenance of equipment and of spare parts. In January the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya reduced foreign exchange alloca- tions for certain imports by up to 50 percent and eliminated allocations for others; imports of further items were banned during the year. In April Nigeria added three items to the prohibited list and 29 other items, mostly manufactured goods, to the list of imports subject to import licensing. All imports above a certain value were subjected to a preship- ment import surveillance scheme. In June the issuance of import licenses was restricted to goods 24 that could not be obtained domestically in Nigeria. In September import procedures for a number of commodities were tightened and the number of agencies in Nigeria banned from importing goods was increased. Several non-oil developing countries continued to rationalize and simplify their import regimes and to reduce import restrictions. Bangladesh in- troduced various changes in the import system that on balance represented a liberalization; the most important of these were the substitution of annual for semiannual licenses for some industrial import- ters, the lengthening of the period of validity of import entitlement certificates, the authorization for commercial banks to extend the validity of import licensing or letters of credit, the expansion of the list of items importable under the Wage Earners' Scheme and the Export Performance Licensing Schemes, and the permissibility of deferred pay- ments for imports under the Wage Earners' Scheme. In March Brazil introduced permission for the importation of almost 50 items or groups of items that had been prohibited since January 1977. Ecuador eliminated restrictions on imports of fruits and liquor that previously had been permitted only under barter agreements. In November Haiti lifted the import prohibitions imposed on April 9, 1981 and modified the import tariffs on some products. After subjecting several primary products to quan- titative restrictions and all import licenses to indi- vidual approval in September, Hungary simplified import licensing procedures in January 1983. Up to specified quarterly limits, imports other than capital goods were exempted from the requirement that approval be obtained for each individual license. In April India adopted a package of import liberaliza- tion measures that included the transfer of a number of items to less restrictive import licensing categories; an increase of 10 percent over and above consumption in any of the two preceding years for automatic licenses for 1982/83; the introduction of a repeat license facility; permission to import otherwise prohibited capital goods if such goods would reduce production costs by at least 10 percent; and permission to import certain goods up to certain limits without the usual clearance proce- dures. At the same time, India introduced more liberal special provisions for export-oriented pro- ducers. In January 1983, Jamaica replaced import licenses by import permits that were freely issued up to specified amounts for goods not on the restricted list. Morocco transferred a number of import items to less restricted lists, including raw materials, capital goods, and consumer goods. In ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAIN DEVELOPMENTS IN RESTRICTIVE PRACTICES July, Pakistan liberalized its import system substan- tially by shifting many commodities to the free list, increasing import quotas for commercial importers, and removing licensing requirements for certain goods. In February the Philippines authorized com- mercial banks to sell foreign exchange for payment of imports of certain nonessential and unclassified consumer goods with prior approval of the Central Bank and exempted from certain documentation requirements imports for which no foreign ex- change payment was due. Portugal raised the limit for exemption from prior registration for imports of newspapers and periodicals. Sudan allowed certain commodities to be financed in the legal free foreign exchange market. Thailand allowed free importa- tion of jute fiber and small compressors and accessories for refrigerating equipment, provided that these were used in final products for re- exportation. In January Tunisia issued a revised list of liberalized imports and eliminated requirements for certain import documentation for imports from French franc zone countries. Turkey transferred a number of commodities to less restricted import lists. Import licenses were issued freely by Uganda for all nonprohibited imports effective from late August. The Bahamas and Guyana also lifted licensing requirements for certain imports. The generally difficult balance of payments situation of the non-oil developing countries led many of them to tighten quantitative import restric- tions. Argentina imposed licensing requirements for imports from Australia, Canada, the United Kingdom, and other members of the EC in April. Importation of most consumer goods, representing 10-15 percent of total imports, was also effectively banned. In July Argentina established U .S. dollar limits for imports; separate limits were established for imports in each customs category for each importer. The system of U.S. dollar limits on imports was abolished in October, but the ban on consumer goods was extended to March 31, 1983. In November Bolivia banned the importation of some 600 products considered nonessential or produced domestically. Products covered by the agreements signed within the Latin American Inte- gration Association (LAIA)15 were exempt from this prohibition. In September Brazil banned the importation of a wide range of items manufactured nationally or considered superfluous, including industrial machinery, components and replacement 15The members are Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Mexico, Paraguay, Peru, Uruguay, and Venezuela. parts, as well as raw materials for the chemical, petrochemical, and pharmaceutical industries. The People's Republic of China restricted imports of motor vehicles, television sets, cassette tape record- ers, digital wristwatches, refrigerators, cameras, and certain other consumer goods. Colombia inten- sified import restrictions, especially during the second half of 1982. License requirements were imposed on more than 510 tariff items that pre- viously could be imported freely. Furthermore, the enterprises in the fields of exploration, exploitation, or transformation of mineral products, with certain exceptions, were required to obtain licenses for their imports every six months. The Dominican Republic in August suspended imports of certain agricultural goods, construction equipment, house- hold electronic products, automobiles and trucks for a period of one year and imports of women's clothing for an indefinite period. In November the Dominican Republic set quotas for 1983 imports of raw materials and consumer goods to be paid with foreign exchange provided by the central bank equivalent to 45 percent of the average value of these imports during 1979 and 1980. Quotas for imports of medicines, raw materials for the phar- maceutical industry, and infant food were set at their 1982 levels. In November Ecuador prohibited the importation of a number of items representing 25 percent of the total value of imports. Egypt expanded the list of goods whose importation is subject to approval by the Ministry of Economy and Foreign Trade, and enlarged the functions of the Import Rationalization Committee. In November Guatemala published a list of those products that were made subject to prior import licensing. Malta introduced a ban on the import of Japanese goods and goods that could be produced domestically. In early 1983 Lebanon also introduced several mea- sures to prevent such exports. In September Mexico imposed prior licensing requirements for all im- ports; however, in December requirements for certain imports were lifted. Peru subjected various goods to prior import licensing, including several iron and steel products, nuclear raw materials and components, and accessories for nuclear reactors. The Philippines increased the list of import items subject to prior approval or certification and pro- hibited the importation of certain agricultural goods. In January, Sudan banned imports of textiles and yarns, passenger cars and pickups, canned food, plastic products, household appliances, sta- tionery, tires, sweets, and certain other goods. Suriname tightened the import regime in January by prohibiting imports of certain consumer goods, 25 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS imposing quotas on imports of certain garments, and expanding the list of goods to be imported by the public central import service. In February Thailand imposed licensing requirements on all trade with South Africa. Licensing was also re- quired for imports of a few selected goods, and restrictions were imposed on imports of oil plant products, fishmeal, and single-cylinder diesel engines. In November Tunisia banned certain im- port items and imposed quotas on a number of food and beverage products. Venezuela, as part of a general tightening of the import system, prohibited imports of some 200 agricultural and industrial products in November. At the same time, the government became the sole importer of some items, and tariffs were raised on others. In October Yugoslavia limited the importation of personal belongings and gifts by Yugoslav nationals return- ing from abroad and prohibited direct importation by residents for household needs. Exceptions con- tinued to apply to holders of foreign exchange accounts and for Yugoslav workers employed abroad. On a more selective basis, certain imports were banned in Ethiopia and Nepal and subjected to import licensing requirements in Dominica, Fiji, Haiti, Honduras, and Sri Lanka. Import Surcharges and Import Taxation There were few major actions relating directly to the use of across-the-board surcharges and similar measures during 1982, compared with previous years. Israel introduced in June a 3 percent addi- tional ad valorem duty on all imports subject to the value-added tax, which would remain in effect until April 1, 1983. Grenada increased the stamp duty on imports by 2.5 percentage points in January and in March introduced an import surcharge on goods subject to stamp duty at a rate of 2 percent of their c .i .f. value. In late 1982 the stamp duty was raised further by 5 percentage points, to 17.5 percent. In its 1982 budget, Morocco announced a specific stamp duty on all imports above a certain value. Pakistan imposed an across-the-board import sur- charge of 5 percent on all imports in Ju ly, and customs duties were lowered on 11 items and raised on 13 other items. In February South Africa imposed a 10 percent surcharge on imports other than petroleum products, products subject to GATT bindings, and imports for government use; in December 1982 this surcharge rate was reduced to 7.5 percent, and to 5.0 percent in February 1983. During 1982 Thailand increased the items that were subject to import surcharges and increased rates on 26 already existing surcharges for various com- modities. From June to November, Uruguay im- posed a 10 percent tariff surcharge on all imports. Import surcharges on limited categories of goods were introduced in Djibouti, Hungary, and Turkey. In the area of import taxation, preference-giving countries made further concessions under the Gen- eralized System of Preferences (GSP), albeit mod- est ones, in their tariffs applied to imports from developing countries. These concessions, espe- cially to least developed countries, included addi- tions to the beneficiary lists, expansion of product coverage, and deeper tariff cuts. The Austrian Customs Preference Act 1982, which covers the second ten-year period of the GSP in that country, provides for a special tariff treatment for imports from 31 least developed countries. For industrial products originating in least developed countries, duty-free treatment is granted across the board, with the exception of textiles, for which a 50 percent tariff cut is applied. Spain and Greece ceased to be beneficiaries under the Austrian GSP system, and Portugal and Turkey were reclassified with the majority of the preference-receiving coun- tries. Certain products were also added to the Austrian GSP scheme, and preferential tariff treat- ment for other products was improved. At the beginning of 1982 Canada reduced most-favored- nation (MFN) tariffs in line with the schedule agreed in the Multilateral Trade Negotiations (MTN); at that time proportionate reductions were also made in many GSP rates for developing countries. The EC's GSP, which was introduced for a ten-year period in January 1981, remained in effect during 1982. At the end of 1982 some minor changes in product coverage and quotas were made to the EC scheme for 1983, in favor of the least developed countries. As in 1982, the list of ben- eficiaries for 1983 contains 125 countries, but Togo and Sierra Leone were added to the list of least developed countries. The People's Republic of China and Romania continue to benefit from GSP preferences under special arrangements for a some- what broader range of products. Some amendments were made to Finland's GSP scheme, effective September 1, by which Antigua and Barbuda, Belize, and Vanuatu were included in the list of beneficiary countries and Guinea-Bissau was trans- ferred to the list of least developed countries. Certain products were added to the list of products eligible for GSP preferences, along with coffee imported from least developed countries. On April 1, when Japan effected across-the-board tariff reductions on a large number of items two years ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAIN DEVELOPMENTS IN RESTRICTIVE PRACTICES ahead of the schedule agreed on during the Tokyo Round of the Multilateral Trade Negotiations, GSP rates that had been higher than reduced MFN rates were reduced to the level of MFN duties. In October GSP rate reductions were made in step with the two-year advanced implementation of Tokyo Round MFN concessions. Furthermore, ceilings for GSP entry were increased by 6.75 percent in the fiscal year 1981/82. With the inclu- sion of Guinea-Bissau, a total of 30 countries are accorded special preferential treatment as least developing countries under the Japanese GSP sys- tem. Imports by Norway of textile apparels and of certain engines for motor vehicles became eligible for GSP treatment in October. In October 1981 Switzerland extended the scheme of tariff prefer- ences for a ten-year period beginning 1982. An amendment envisages the possibility of adapting preferential treatment to the conditions prevailing in a preference-receiving country. With effect from March, imports of certain industrial products from the 31 least developed countries were permitted to enter Switzerland duty free. Duty-free treatment was also accorded for 48 agricultural products, of which 24 had not been part of the Swiss scheme of preferences. The margin of preferences was in- creased on a few products from certain countries. Since January 1982 the United States added 77 new products to the eligible list for the GSP and has extended cumulative treatment under the GSP to the Caribbean Common Market (CARICOM).16 Also, pursuant to a procedure referred to as "graduation" introduced by the United States in 1981, by which GSP eligibility could be withdrawn selectively from certain countries and areas on a product-by-product basis, Brazil, Hong Kong, Israel, Republic of Korea, Mexico, and Singapore were removed from eligibility on certain products. In April 1982 Hun- gary extended its general duty-free treatment of imports from the least developed countries to imports from Guinea-Bissau. With regard to generalized tariff measures, Japan put into effect various measures during 1982 to reduce tariff barriers to foreign goods. With effect from April 1, tariffs on 1,653 items were reduced across the board, two years ahead of the schedule 16 Cumulative treatment allows two or more member coun- tries of an eligible association to contribute jointly to the requirement that at least 35 percent of the value added of the product in question originate in the beneficiary country. The CARICOM countries are Antigua and Barbuda, Barbados, Belize, Dominica, Grenada, Guyana, Jamaica, Montserrat, St. Kitts-Nevis, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and Grenadines, and Trinidad and Tobago. agreed upon during the Tokyo Round of Multila- teral Trade Negotiations. The average tariff rate for these items was reduced to 6.75 percent in fiscal year 1981/82 from 8 percent in the previous year. In May the Japanese Government announced an eight- point trade liberalization package, which included the decision to abolish import tariffs on 97 indus- trial items as of April 1983, and to lower them on an additional 131 items, of which 17 were agricul- tural. The products covered by the above tariff actions were equivalent to 9.0 percent of the total value of Japan's imports of dutiable goods (exclud- ing petroleum) in 1981. On January 13, 1983 the Japanese Government announced another package of market liberalization measures to become effec- tive as of April 1, 1983. Among the measures announced were the reductions of tariffs on bis- cuits, chocolates, 8 tobacco products, 16 manufac- tured products, and 46 agricultural goods and the elimination of tariffs on 12 manufactured products and 1 category of agricultural goods. Among other industrial countries, Iceland reduced or abolished customs duties and special excise taxes on a wide range of products during the first half of 1982, including various inputs for import competing industries; in August a number of commodities became subject to the special excise tax, and the rates of the special import tax on automobiles were raised. Several non-oil developing countries lowered their import tariffs, mostly on a selective basis. In May Argentina reduced import duties 1-5 percent- age points depending upon the initial duty level. Brazil granted customs duty exemptions or reduc- tions, including many reductions to zero rates, for various imported goods throughout 1982; the reduc- tions or exemptions were often restricted to certain purposes or end users and were granted on a temporary basis. In certain instances, reduced rates were subject to tying arrangements whereby a minimum quantity of domestic products was re- quired to be purchased along with the imported product. Whenever quotas limited the access to preferential rates or exemptions, preference was, at times, to be given to imports from member coun- tries of the LAI A. Furthermore, the rate of the tax on financial operations was reduced to zero for imports of soybeans and unrefined soybean oil. The People's Republic of China changed the import duties on 149 items in January. As a result, duties were reduced on imports of rubber, timber, leather, pulp, paper, raw materials for the energy industry, machinery and equipment and parts for the light and textile industries, but were raised on imports of 27 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS certain machinery and equipment items produced in the People's Republic of China. Colombia ex- empted certain goods from tariffs and reduced import duties on a wide range of products. In addition, duties on imports of specified products from Peru and Venezuela were reduced according to a schedule leading to elimination of duties by 1984. India reduced import duties on a wide range of goods, including certain metals, raw materials, machinery, synthetic fibers, and exempted from duty imports of certain specified drugs, fertilizers, pig iron, and goods imported in connection with offshore oil exploration or exploitation. Indonesia granted a partial exemption from import duties and import sales taxes for various goods and expanded the list of imports eligible for preferential tariff treatment under the ASEAN agreement. Mexico announced in March a program to reduce import duties for some 1,500 items ranging from raw materials, intermediate goods, and capital goods to certain basic commodities of general consumption. In December import duties on items financed in the controlled exchange market were reduced by 10 percentage points. In November Peru exempted a number of agricultural inputs from import tariffs. Tunisia exempted from import duties certain prod- ucts for investment projects and reduced the duties on several other items in June. In November Uganda reduced the import duties on a wide range of goods by between 30 percent and 50 percent. Effective January 1, 1983, Uruguay took substantial measures to liberalize the trade system. The highest import duty rate was lowered from 75 percent to 55 percent, and the number of different import duty rates was reduced. With the aim of improving efficiency in domestic industry, the minimum im- port prices maintained by Uruguay's central bank were eliminated; import reference prices have since been maintained or established only as antidumping devices. As already mentioned, the special 10 percent export rebate-import surcharge, introduced in mid-1982, was eliminated at the same time. Selective taxes on imports were also eliminated in Singapore and the Yemen Arab Republic. Several non-oil developing countries imposed new or raised existing taxes or duties on imports. Chile increased specific duties on dairy products, twice during the course of 1982, and in November increased tariffs temporarily by an average of 17 points on 12 other products. Djibouti extended the 5 percent tax levied on the c.i.f. value of most goods other than food or beverages originating in non-EC countries to imports of these goods from EC countries. In March Greece raised taxes on im- 28 ported consumer goods. In April India increased the rates of the auxiliary customs duty on all imported goods, with certain exceptions, by 5 percent. Moreover, duties were increased substantially dur- ing 1982 on a wide range of goods, including cement, electronic items, and iron and steel. India withdrew Commonwealth preferences from a num- ber of countries, excluding Mauritius, Seychelles, and Tonga. Ivory Coast increased the value-added tax on imports; the increases ranged between 4.5 percent and 6.4 percent. Haiti imposed a sales tax of 7 percent on all imports, with minor exceptions. In January Peru replaced the sales and services tax on imports by a uniform value-added tax of 16 percent on the c . i .f. value of imports (in addition to the import duty). Simultaneously, a selective con- sumption tax was levied on luxury items, ranging from 10 percent to 40 percent of the c . i . f. value. Other selective increases in import duties were effected in Belize, Colombia, the People's Re- public of China, Malaysia, Pakistan, and Yugoslavia. Among oil-exporting countries, Nigeria in- troduced new or higher rates of import duties for 42 groups of items. In addition, user concession duties were introduced for rubberized textile fabrics, completely knocked down components, generators and certain engines, and a 500 percent ad valorem duty was imposed on passenger cars, which were taken off the prohibited list. In November Qatar raised the import duty on tobacco and cigarettes from 10 percent to 30 percent. Other member countries of the Gulf Cooperation Council (Bah- rain, Kuwait, Oman, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates) also announced subsequently that they would take similar measures. Saudi Arabia in July imposed a duty on imports of lubricating oils at the rate of 20 percent for three years. The United Arab Emirates subjected all imports into Dubai and Sharjah to a customs duty of 1 percent of the c . i .f. value. As part of a general revision of the import tariff system, Venezuela in June lowered duties on about 550 tariff items by up to 95 percent and raised them on more than 300 other tariff items by an average of over 30 percentage points. Advance Import Deposits In 1982 the reliance of Fund members on advance import deposit schemes decreased further. Nine countries eliminated or reduced the scope of their schemes, and one country (Kenya) announced the intention to terminate the scheme as of ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAIN DEVELOPMENTS IN RESTRICTIVE PRACTICES January 31, 1983. Four countries introduced or expanded their existing schemes. In February and May Colombia reduced the rate of the advance import deposit requirement from 35 percent to 10 percent. In February the rate of the advance exchange license deposit was also reduced from 95 percent to 80 percent. In January Greece reduced the rates for advanced import deposits for specified imports by a third, to one half of the level prevailing before January 1, 1981. In February Italy abolished the advance import deposit requirement introduced in May 1981. Kenya announced in December that the remaining advance import de- posit requirements would be abolished as of Jan- uary 31, 1983. In February and March Morocco reduced the number of products subject to a 25 percent advance import deposit requirement. Paki- stan, in January exempted raw materials used by the iron, steel, and shipbreaking industries from a 25 percent margin requirement against import letters of credit. In February the Philippines modified the rate schedule of its 100 percent margin deposits on import letters of credit, as follows: the deposit fate would be 90 percent for letters of credit opened on or after March 1; 80 percent if opened after April 1; 70 percent if opened after May 1; 60 percent if opened after June 1; and 50 percent if opened after July 1. In October the Syrian Arab Republic reduced the rate of the advance import deposit requirement applicable to foodstuff, raw materials, and pharmaceutical chemical products from 25 percent to 10 percent. Turkey reduced the rate of the import guarantee deposit requirement for certain types of fertilizer, pesticides, and wheat from 10 percent to 1 percent in January. Uganda, in Octo- ber, suspended its 5 percent advance import deposit requirement. Advance import deposit requirements were in- troduced by four countries and tightened in one, Ecuador. In Egypt, importers were required with effect from March to lodge with the commercial banks non-interest-bearing deposits in convertible foreign exchange ranging from 25 percent to 100 percent of the c . i . f. value of imports at the time of opening of letters of credit. In January Iceland reintroduced for one year the 35 percent advance deposit requirement on furniture imports, which had previously been abolished in December 1980; deposits were required to be held in interest-bearing blocked accounts for 90 days prior to importation. In May Honduras introduced a 100 percent guaran- tee deposit requirement against sight letters of credit. Nigeria introduced, in April, an advance import deposit requirement ranging from 25 percent to 250 percent, as follows: 25 percent for raw materials and spare parts; 50 percent for books, food (excluding rice), medicaments, building mate- rials, and capital goods; 200 percent for motor vehicles other than automobiles; and 250 percent for automobiles and other goods. In October Ecuador tightened the advance import deposit re- quirement by subjecting certain categories of im- ports to the 20 percent requirement and by raising the rates on others. As a result of the changes, the range of deposit requirements rose from 15-50 percent to 20-80 percent of the c . i .f. value of imports; the terms of deposits remained unchanged at 180-270 days. Other Measures Affecting Import Payments During 1982 regulations governing the terms of or the procedures for import payments were mod- ified in a number of countries. On balance, most of the changes involved the tightening of the terms of, or the procedures for, import payments. In November Bolivia required that all import payments be covered by letters of credit. In October Brazil tightened the minimum payment terms for imports with exchange cover, as follows: (a) from seven to eight years for payments for imports of machinery and equipment in excess of US$1 mil- lion and less than US$5 million; (b) from 180 days to one year for import payments for industrial durable consumer goods; and (c) a maximum of 10 percent of import value as down payments for all imports. Chile, in April, reduced the maximum terms for import payments from 90 days to 45 days and in July eliminated the maximum terms. Ecuador, in October, announced a requirement that at least 80 percent of the f.o.b. value of capital goods imports be financed with credits having maturities of at least 360 days, and in November fixed the minimum financing period for imports of spare parts and tools at 180 days. In November Greece restricted purchases of foreign exchange by importers to within four days prior to the date of payment. In April Hungary ceased to grant waivers to importers in respect of the domestic currency deposits for import payments and made more restrictive the extension of short-term credits by the National Bank to finance the borrowed portion of these deposits. In April Indonesia required that public sector imports be shipped by vessels oper- ated by companies owned by Indonesians. Italy, in April, prohibited prepayments for imports of goods and services before the contractual due date and 29 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS reduced from 30 days to 15 days the period for using foreign currencies purchased in advance of import transactions. In September Mexico required that all payments for imports originating in Argen- tina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Paraguay, Peru, Uruguay, Venezuela, and Yugoslavia be made through set- tlement accounts within the framework of various reciprocal credit and payment agreements between the Bank of Mexico and the central bank of each country. Mexico also introduced, in September, a prior import requirement, under which import permits were classified as permitted imports with foreign exchange made available, other permitted imports, and banned imports. Certain personal items and goods with values not exceeding Mex$5,000 were exempted from the requirement. In March Nigeria suspended the issuance of letters of credit and the processing of forms used to release foreign exchange. In October the Syrian Arab Republic required most import settlements to be effected by letters of credit. During the period under review, several coun- tries modified procedures for import transactions. In August, Bangladesh also allowed authorized dealers to buy on their own account import entitle- ment certificates issued under the Export Perfor- mance Licensing Scheme from exporters at prices that would reflect the spread between the dealers' spot buying rate for foreign exchange and the official spot selling rate for foreign exchange. Import entitlement certificates so purchased could, at the dealers' option, be sold to Bangladesh banks by adding a margin of Tk 0.015 per U .S. dollar and Tk 0.025 per pound sterling. In December, Ban- gladesh allowed imports, on a deferred payments basis, of all raw materials, spare parts, and con- sumer goods permitted by import licenses and letters of credit authorization forms issued against cash or under the Export Performance License Scheme. Colombia, in February, extended the maximum terms for import payments to 180 days, and in November lengthened the minimum terms for financing of certain essential imports from 6 months to 9 months. In January the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya permitted the commercial banks to transfer funds abroad on behalf of foreign contrac- tors without the specific approval of the Central Bank in payment for imports of equipment in accordance with the terms specified in the con- tracts. Pakistan, in June, extended to six months the permissible period for forward foreign exchange cover in respect of imports other than crude oil and 30 petroleum products, and government imports, and in respect of sales of foreign exchange to overseas banks' branches and correspondents to cover rupee bills negotiated by them under letters of credit established by authorized dealers in Pakistan. In September Pakistan permitted import letters of credit to be opened in any foreign currency. During 1982, Argentina introduced a number of changes in the import payments procedures that had both liberalizing and restricting effects on import transactions. In January the prohibition on pay- ments for imports before the due date was re- scinded, except that payments before the due date for imports of capital goods valued at more than US$5 million continued to require the approval of the Central Bank. In April payments of up to 20 percent of the f .o .b. value of capital goods imports in advance of shipments were temporarily pro- hibited. In May minimum financing terms of at least 180 days were established for most imports shipped on or after May 24; however, a lower minimum financing period of 90 days was applied to imports originating in or shipped from member countries of the LAI A, member countries of the Central American Common Market, and Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Haiti, and Panama. Payments against shipping documents were permitted for the following: (a) goods on the "negotiated list" ship- ped from, and originating in, LAI A member coun- tries; (b) goods imported by firms located in the National Territories of Tierra del Fuego, Antarc- tica, and the Islands of the South Atlantic and destined for the Special Customs Area; (c) fresh fru i ts, and (d) newspapers and other periodicals. In August minimum financing terms for imports of capital goods valued at more than US$50,000 were established. Not more than 5 percent of the f .o .b. value could be paid in advance and an additional 10 percent could be paid upon the submission of shipping documents. The balance of 85 percent was to be paid in equal installments beginning not more than six months after shipment in accordance with a specified schedule. Exempted from these require- ments were imports of capital goods covered by 85 percent financing from international organizations or official creditors and imports by firms located in the National Territories of Tierra del Fuego, Ant- arctica, and the Islands of the South Atlantic. State Trading In the period under review there were few changes in members' state-trading practices. The four changes reported to the Fund involved state ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MA IN DEVELOPMENTS IN RESTRICTIVE PRACTICES monopolies on export trade. Burundi abolished an export monopoly for hides in January. In Ju ly Pakistan allowed the exportation of sugar by the private sector. In April, Peru entrusted the National Coffee Board with the distribution of the export quota, and Vanuatu gave monopoly rights on exports of copra to the Vanuatu Commodities Marketing Board. Exports and Export Proceeds Reflecting the difficult international trading en- vironment, measures taken during the period under review affecting exports and export proceeds mainly provided incentives to exports or were intended to ensure the prompt repatriation and surrender of export proceeds. Quantitative restrictions on exports were abol- ished or relaxed in a few countries. In Ju ly Pakistan abrogated the ban on the export of chemical fertilizer and sugar, although the former was still required to be exported by the public sector. Thailand reduced the rice reserve requirement on two occasions in January and February and abol- ished it in May, together with the termination of the cash payment requirement for rice exports. Thai- land also effected the following: in January, the Government lifted the ban on exports of steel bars, relaxed the restrictions on the export of vegetable cooking oil, wood-free paper, newsprint, kenaf paper, and coconut or palm sugar containing cane sugar; in February, it lifted the ban on exports of cement subject to the domestic availability of minimum reserves of 300,000 tons and abolished the export quota for coffee; and in Ju ly, it lifted quantitative restrictions on maize exports for the 1982/83 season. In July Uganda lifted all the remaining quantitative restrictions on agricultural exports. A number of countries tightened or introduced quotas, bans and embargoes on exports. In April Argentina established controls on exports of goods needed for national defense and security. Con- versely, Canada imposed an embargo on shipments to Argentina of arms or other goods that could be used for military purposes during the April- December period. In July Colombia set a quota of 80,000 tons for rice exports. Mali banned the export of cereals in November. Nepal banned the export of logs and sawn logs in January and rice in March, although the latter measure was temporarily suspended from May to August. Thailand imposed quotas on tin exports in April, in conformity with the International Tin Agreement, and tightened the conditions for the issuance of export certificates for tapioca products in June in alignment with the reduction in the EC quota for world exports. The United States virtually banned, through the imposi- tion of export licensing requirements, exports to the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya of national security items as well as of high technology oil and gas equipment that was not readily available outside the United States. In April the United States imposed sanctions against Argentina, including suspension of all military exports, new Export-Import Bank credits, and new commodity credit guarantees; the eco- nomic sanctions, except for the military ones, were lifted in Ju ly. During the June-November period, the United States banned the export to the U .S .S .R. of oil and gas equipment produced by subsidiaries of U.S. companies abroad as well as produced abroad under licenses issued by U .S. companies. In August Venezuela eliminated the export licensing requirement for potatoes and plantains. Licensing requirements were tightened in two coun- tries during the period under review. Liberia added wheat offals and dry brewer's grain to the list of exports subject to licensing requirements. Thailand introduced in February licensing requirements for exports to South Africa, while the prior approval requirement was lifted regarding exports of tapioca products to the EC in February and exports of orchids in March. New fiscal measures to promote exports were taken by a number of developing country members, particularly by countries in Latin America. In September Argentina extended its tax rebate scheme to sugar exports at a special rate of 25 percent, which was reduced to 10 percent in November. In Brazil, various exports became eligi- ble for tax credits: vaseline and certain vegetable oil products in April; cassava starch and essences for use in soft drinks, in May; pectin, in Ju ly; bread and certain other bakery products, in September; certain corn products, including corn flour and unrefined corn oil, in October; and scheelite (a tungsten compound) and unrefined nickel, in November. Also, in November the export tax credit of 11 percent, which was to be reduced and eliminated by March 31,1983, was extended until April 30, 1985. In August Colombia raised the rates of tax credit certificates granted to exporters to 5-15 percent. In November Greece decided to speed up tax refunds on exported goods and to raise the proportion of a company's export earnings that could be deducted for income tax purposes from 1.5 percent to 3.0 percent. In November Haiti exempted export indus- 31 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS tries involved in the assembly of imported parts or materials on a contract basis from the payment of the consular fee on such imports. In January, Nepal provided grants on a per metric ton basis for exports of hessian, sacking, and twine to countries other than India. In January Pakistan added domesti- cally produced engineering goods supplied locally against international tender to the eligible goods for the export rebate scheme as well as for the preferential export finance scheme, and in March, export rebates for hand-knotted carpets and rugs were extended retroactively to shipments after January 1, 1982. In November, Peru extended eligible items under the export incentives scheme to cover local sales of industrial inputs and raw materials for nontraditional manufactured exports. Uruguay extended the coverage of tax credit certifi- cates to a wide range of manufactured products until November, when the authorities replaced them by a system of reimbursement of 5 percent of indirect tax charges on all exports. There was only one instance in which incentives were withdrawn. In April South Africa discon- tinued the granting of specially reduced railroad rates and aid in respect of finance charges ("the Finance Charges Aid Scheme") to exporters. In addition, Peru implemented the registration require- ment system for the granting of tax benefits for nontraditional exports. Several countries abolished or reduced export taxes and duties. Brazil reduced the export taxes on beef cattle hides and orange juice in February and June, respectively, and exempted leather shoes from the export tax scheme in July. In February India abolished the export duty on groundnuts and also reduced the rate of export duty on chromite ore and concentrate to 5 percent ad valorem. In July Mauritius reduced the rate of surcharge on sugar exports from 75 percent to 50 percent. In January Nepal waived the export duties and excise taxes on major export items (jute, cardamom, dry ginger, tea, herbs, and ready-made garments). At the same time, the export duties on leather products were reduced. In February Nicaragua lowered the rates of export taxes on major agricultural products (molasses, sesame, cotton, beef, sugar, and cof- fee). In January Thailand decided to provide all categories of exports containing imported raw materials with eligibility for import duty rebates. Several countries imposed new or raised existing taxes or duties on exports for revenue or domestic supply reasons. In May Argentina introduced an emergency export duty of $a 1,000 per US$1 on some traditional agricultural and livestock exports. 32 In Ju ly, export taxes on a variety of items were raised and rebates for promoted exports were reduced. In November Bolivia temporarily in- creased or introduced taxes on nontraditional ex- ports. In August Brazil declared that it would tax its steel exports to the United States. Taxes were introduced later on the following items: carbon steel plates in September, machine wire in October, and prestressed concrete reinforcing wire in November. In February Indonesia introduced new procedures for collecting an export tax and revised rates of additional export taxes on various agricultural and forestry products for the period April-December. A number of countries provided new or extended existing preferential financing facilities for exports. In September Argentina introduced a new special lending program under which exporters of pro- moted exports could obtain 180-day preferential loans. In October Austria raised the ceiling for export financing at preferential rates from S 8 billion to S 9 billion. In June Bangladesh an- nounced that export credit for nontraditional items would be made available at a rate of interest not exceeding the Bangladesh Bank rate by more than 1 percent. In July Bangladesh reduced the rate of interest on export credit for nontraditional items from 12 percent to 11.5 percent. In September Bangladesh reduced the rate on refinancing facilities against export credit in respect of nontra- ditional items from 9 percent to 8 percent; the coverage of the latter rate was also extended. In April Chile raised the maximum maturity for preshipment export credit to 270 days. The period within which shipment must take place was also raised from 210 days to 240 days. In January Colombia broadened the preshipment credit to ex- porters of products other than coffee, oil and oil derivatives, and gold; export credits could be redis- countable at the Central Bank and could bear a 15 percent rate of interest; 100 percent of exports could be financed, up to 1 year for exports of consumer goods and up to 5 years for exports of capital goods. In February Colombia established a special line of credit for exports to facilitate marketing research, advertising campaigns, and participation in fairs and shows abroad. In March a line of credit was established for exporters of mechanical prod- ucts in order to purchase quality control and packing equipment. In May a special line of credit was established for exporters of products other than coffee, castor oil and oil products, and precious stones to finance their technical assistance expan- sion. In November Greece extended the period during which some exporters could benefit from ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAIN DEVELOPMENTS IN RESTRICTIVE PRACTICES credits with a low interest rate of 10 percent. In April India excluded de-oiled rice bran from the cash compensatory support scheme. Further, a number of changes were implemented in October to rationalize the scheme, including a reduction in cash assistance to export commodities which have accumulated sufficient export capability; the exclu- sion from the scheme of export commodities that have limited export potential; and an increase in cash support for export commodities which have received insufficient support in the past despite their medium-term export potential. In January Indonesia introduced an export credit facility under which a preferential rate was made available by state banks. Sixty percent of the credits were made rediscountable at 3 percent at Bank Indonesia. In August Pakistan extended the period of repayments under the export financing scheme from 180 days to 270 days for carpets and leather products. To monitor export performance and borrowing entitle- ment, Pakistan imposed, in September, a penalty system under the export financing scheme. In November the export financing scheme was fuither modified so that the receipt, instead of the confir- mation, was required to be provided with export finance. In April, Thailand extended the export bill rediscount facility offered by the Bank of Thailand so as to make sugar exports eligible for the facility. In the area of export guarantees, Argentina introduced in August a scheme under which autho- rized agencies could purchase exchange proceeds forward from exporters and obtain cover for this operation from the Central Bank. In March Colom- bia allowed payment of 90 percent of the premium for insurances against certain kinds of risks, appli- cable to Central American and Caribbean countries. In May the scheme of export credit insurance was extended to exporters of services to Central America and the Caribbean area so that commercial risks were covered up to 90 percent, while political risks were covered up to 100 percent. In January Indonesia instituted a facility to cover the risk of nonpayment by foreign buyers with premiums ranging from 0.2 percent to 4 percent of the value of exports. At the same time, a new export credit guarantee facility was established providing credit guarantee at 0.5 percent of export value for a period up to 6 months, 0.75 percent for a period of from 6 to 9 months, and 1 percent for a period of from 9 to 12 months. In March Israel extended the export insurance scheme for unfavorable developments in domestic currency costs relative to the average weighted exchange rate of the Israel shekel against five major foreign currencies. Repatriation and surrender requirements were liberalized in a number of countries. In August Argentina permitted exporters to surrender the exchange proceeds for promoted exports in excess of the targeted amount at the financial market rate. In March Bolivia lowered the export surrender requirement to 40 percent of proceeds net of commercialization charges and of royalty payments denominated in foreign exchange. In February Colombia extended the maximum term for repatria- tion of export proceeds to 15 months whenever exporters likewise extended credits to the foreign importers; for goods sold on a commission basis the term was extended to 24 months; for books and other printed material, to 18 months; for capital goods, to 3 years; and for authorized capital goods, to 5 years and 3 months. In July the term for repatriation of proceeds of exports other than coffee was raised to one year from the date of approval of the export registration, and the term for exports of capital goods was extended to five years. In August Costa Rica reduced the proportion of export pro- ceeds to be surrendered at the official rate from 10 percent to 5 percent; the remaining 95 percent was to be surrendered at the banking rate. Hungary raised the limit of exemption from the surrender requirement for foreign exchange from the equiva- lent of Ft 400 to Ft 2,000 a person. In January Indonesia abolished the surrender requirements on export receipts. Italy extended in September the time allowed for lagged settlements on account of exports from 60 days to 90 days; it was extended to 120 days in November. In January 1983 Jamaica allowed exporters of nontraditional products to retain up to 50 percent of their foreign exchange proceeds in the form of negotiable claims, which in turn provided automatic access to import permits for spare parts, capital goods, and raw materials. In October Mexico allowed exporting companies and tourism companies to open special accounts. Ex- porting companies were authorized (1) to deposit foreign exchange accruing from exports, foreign financing, and other receipts from abroad; (2) to convert the deposits into pesos at the ordinary exchange rate; and (3) to use up to 70 percent of the receipts from their accounts for expenses associated with exports. In December Mexico decided that the special deposits by exporters in local currency could only be effected with proceeds from exports, and that they would earn an interest rate equivalent to the rate of depreciation of the peso against the U.S. dollar plus the interest rate payable on Eurodollar deposits. In December commercial banks could no longer credit the special compensa- 33 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS tory accounts of exporting companies and tourism companies in order to increase the ability of the account holder to purchase foreign exchange. In December, Sierra Leone lowered the proportion of export receipts that had to be surrendered at the official exchange rate to the Bank of Sierra Leone. Several countries tightened regulations govern- ing the surrender of export proceeds. In November Bolivia reinstated the requirement that all export receipts be surrendered to the Central Bank. In September Chile reduced from US$5,000 to US$1,000 the amount exporters were allowed to retain for up to 150 days before repatriation. In November El Salvador required exporters of specified nontraditional products to countries out- side Central America to sell the export proceeds to the commercial banks and the mortgage bank for use in the parallel market, or to deposit them in special foreign currency deposit accounts with authorized banks exclusively for use of their own imports of goods and services. In March France reduced the maximum period during which export- ers were required to surrender their export proceeds, from 30 days to 15 days from the date of shipment. In November Greece reduced the period during which exporters had to repatriate export proceeds, from 6 months to 3 months. In August Mexico required, in conformity with the establishment of a dual market, all export receipts of petroleum to be surrendered at the appreciated official exchange rate; in September all export receipts were made, in principle, subject to surrender at the ordinary exchange rate. In April Portugal announced that when settlement for exports occurred later than 120 days after customs clearance, the exchange rate prevailing on the 120th day would be applied. In December Turkey modified the arrangement for the retention and transfer of specified proportions of export earnings (50 percent of export proceeds of mining products and manufactures and 10 percent for fresh vegetables, fruits, and fish) so that exporters could use such foreign exchange entitle- ments under the arrangement only for their own import requirements. Yugoslavia reduced in May the maximum period for the repatriation of export proceeds, from 90 days to 60 days. In October Zambia required exporters to register with the Bank of Zambia before they could be refunded 50 percent of their export proceeds. Several member countries implemented various other measures, mostly with a view to expanding exports. In October Austria signed an oil barter deal with the Islamic Republic of Iran under which Austria would export industrial products, including 34 machinery and energy equipment. In July Bangla- desh abolished the import license permit fee for the importation of machinery for export-oriented industries. In January Indonesia issued guidelines for the new export counterpurchase policy whereby certain imports by the Government and public sector enterprises had to be linked to the export of non-oil products from Indonesia. Indonesia also an- nounced, in January, the abolishment of the re- quirement that exporters had to open letters of credit and improved customs procedures, including 24-hour handling of exports and a simplification of the processing of export documents. In August Nicaragua agreed to open a US$20 million line of credit with the Central Bank of Costa Rica for use by Nicaraguan exporters to Costa Rica. Con- versely, Costa Rica agreed to consolidate and reschedule US$70 million of short-term debt of Nicaragua over seven years. In March Sri Lanka subjected inward remittances of foreign exchange proceeds from exports in excess of US$50,000 a transaction to prior approval by the Controller of Exchange. Thailand relaxed the regulation on the export of black matpe in March and abolished the minimum export prices for shredded and pelletized tapioca in April. Current Invisibles In 1982 the trend of changes in regulations on current invisibles by Fund members was, on bal- ance, toward greater restrictiveness. As in recent years, most of the measures taken were with respect to allowances or exchange allocations for tourism and other travel abroad. To a lesser extent, steps were also taken affecting remittances of incomes and profits, and imports and exports of bank notes and coin. Many developing countries intensified existing restrictions, both for balance of payments reasons and to prevent unauthorized capital trans- fers. Nevertheless liberalization of regulations re- garding foreign exchange allowance for travel, transactions relating to travel, medical expenses, or study abroad occurred in several countries during 1982. Algeria, Bangladesh, Brazil, Cyprus, and Sierra Leone raised exchange allocations for var- ious types of travel abroad. Colombia eliminated a ceiling on purchases of foreign exchange by foreign tourists leaving the country. Hungary increased allowances for travel to member countries of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (CMEA) and automatically entitled Hungarian residents ev- ery third year to allowances for travel outside the ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAIN DEVELOPMENTS IN RESTRICTIVE PRACTICES CMEA area; these allowances were also raised in 1982. Hotels were permitted to credit to a retention account foreign currency collected in excess of targets established by the Bank of Jamaica. Israel established a surcharge for residents' foreign travel in June, but removed it in September. Morocco increased foreign exchange allowances for students abroad. Pakistan raised its foreign exchange quota for private travel abroad and liberalized certain restrictions affecting business travel abroad. Other changes in Pakistan included increasing foreign exchange allowances for study abroad. Turkey relaxed its restrictions on tourist travel. In Uganda quantitative limits on travel and on emigrant and expatriate remittances were raised substantially. In January Zambia lifted restrictions on holiday allow- ances but in February imposed a levy on sales of foreign exchange for travel and education, except government travel, approved medical expenses, and government-sponsored scholarships. In April the levy on sales of foreign exchange for payments abroad for educational purposes was waived ret- roactively. In addition, banks were authorized to give travel allowances to applicants other than their established customers. Many countries tightened regulations governing foreign exchange allocations for travel, education, or medical purposes. Upon their arrival in Algeria, nonresidents were required to purchase a minimum amount of Algerian dinars. In addition, a require- ment was introduced that travel tickets bought by nonresidents for travel abroad be paid for with foreign exchange purchased abroad. Argentina, Chile, Colombia, El Salvador, and Mexico set various limits on the sale of foreign exchange for travel abroad, expenses of students abroad, foreign medical treatment, or family transfers. In Novem- ber, Bolivia established standards and priorities for the Central Bank's allocation of foreign exchange for purposes of foreign travel, students' subsis- tences, and health treatment abroad. In addition, banks, exchange houses, hotels, and travel agencies were permitted to purchase foreign exchange pro- ceeds from tourism, at a premium of 8 percent over the buying rate established by the Central Bank. Besides raising allowances for travel abroad in April, Brazil set an annual limit on purchases of foreign exchange for travel and representation expenditures abroad of exporting companies, and such purchases in excess of the regular individual travel allowance became subject to the tax on financial operations (IOF). In July, the exchange allowance for travel abroad was reduced for non- business trips to South America. In September, the previously liberalized foreign exchange allowance for travel abroad was restricted. Costa Rica placed limits on the amounts of foreign exchange that commercial banks could sell at the free market rate for foreign travel, family remittances, and unregis- tered students; sales exceeding these limits were subject to the authorization of the Central Bank. Dominica placed an ad valorem tax on the purchase of travel tickets. Tourists arriving in Egypt were required to surrender a specific amount of foreign exchange at the commercial bank rate and to produce evidence thereof when settling accounts in certain hotels. Guatemala reduced the annual allo- cation for residents traveling abroad and increased the guarantee deposit requirement for foreign travel. Special regulations became effective regard- ing travel between Hungary and Czechoslovakia that required tourists to possess specified minimum amounts of the currency of their country of destina- tion. Iraq, the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya, and Nigeria reduced certain travel allowances. Tourist operators in Maldives, who had been permitted previously to settle accounts in foreign currency and retain the proceeds, were required to accept only local cur- rency bought by tourists from official money changing institutions for all transactions. In Mex- ico, foreign travelers were required to declare on arrival their foreign exchange holdings and were permitted in turn to convert a certain amount upon departure. Travelers entering or leaving Sudan were required to officially report their foreign exchange holdings, and, in addition, departing travelers were required to provide evidence that any foreign exchange in excess of the allotted amount had been acquired through official channels. The United States placed restrictions on travel-related transac- tions and travel for specific purposes by U .S. citizens to and within Cuba, and no longer autho- rized the processing and payment of credit transac- tions to any person in Cuba. Venezuela raised its travel tax. Yugoslavia announced the requirement that nationals make interest-free deposits for periods of one year for each border crossing associated with private travel. The initial deposit requirement of Din 5,000 would be increased progressively by Din 2,000 for each subsequent crossing within that year. Zambia announced re- strictions on foreign exchange allowances for busi- ness travel abroad by civil servants and employees of parastatal organizations. In October, authorized dealers were no longer allowed to approve business and holiday travel allowances, and holiday allow- ances were suspended for workers on contract with certain forms of resident permit. Zimbabwe set a 35 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS maximum annual limit on foreign exchange for holiday travel that could be accumulated up to three years. Several regulations affecting payments and pro- ceeds for services performed by nonresidents and transfers of income accruing to nonresidents, such as profits, dividends, interest, royalites, and pen- sions, were liberalized during the period under review. Brazil abolished the graduated supplemen- tary tax on remittances of specified dividends paid by investment companies and exempted such com- panies from capital gains tax, while taxing cash dividends and bonuses at a flat rate. Foreign currency deposits made in Brazil after June 17 were exempted from the general requirement that pay- ments of interest and commission not vary from the schedule foreseen in the registration certificate. The People's Republic of China imposed a tax equiva- lent to 5 percent of total revenue on foreign vessels carrying freight and passengers to Chinese ports. In December, the Bank of Mexico authorized the opening of special accounts for the repayment of interest to commercial banks abroad. Colombia reduced the deposit on service payments. In Paki- stan forward cover was made available for repatria- tion of hajj notes collected by correspondents in Saudi Arabia. The Philippines announced that foreign tourists holding visas valid for 59 days could remit up to US$1,000 abroad, but remittances in excess would have to be approved by the Central Bank. Thailand extended through 1982 the exemp- tion from withholding taxes of interest payments for foreign loans of all maturities. Uganda announced that new contracts between companies holding external accounts and the Government of Uganda would incorporate guarantees for the full repatria- tion of profit, dividends, and debt service pay- ments. A maximum annual allowance was allocated for all other invisible payments except education, medical, and advertising expenses. These would continue to be treated on a case-by-case basis. Most changes in 1982 affecting remittances of nonresident income and other service payments were restrictive. Argentina suspended the right under the foreign investment regulations to transfer profits and repatriate investments in April. Foreign obligations arising from profits, dividends, royal- ties, and technical assistance could, with the excep- tion of obligations to U .K. nationals and residents, be paid with U.S. dollar-denominated bonds issued by the Government of Argentina. The Central Bank could approve the transfer of claims below a specified amount through the official exchange market on a case-by-case basis. Bhutan required 36 that all invisible receipts in currencies other than the Indian rupee be surrendered to the Ministry of Finance. Colombia established a minimum term for freight and transportation service payments. The Central Bank of Chile limited the kind of invisible transactions that could be handled by the exchange houses. From November, incomes from personal transfers or received by representatives of foreign countries, residents, and receipts from tourism were required to be sold in El Salvador's parallel ex- change market, and personal transfers could only be deposited in the special foreign currency deposit accounts. In France, transfers of donations to nonresidents were made subject to authorization by the Bank of France. Iraq reduced permissible amounts that certain residents and foreign nationals could transfer abroad in December. In January Guyana prohibited transfers abroad of gifts in the form of cash. In Hungary additional monetary limits were introduced for articles taken out of Hungary by visiting nonresidents from CMEA countries, except Cuba and Viet Nam. The Bank of Sierra Leone lowered limits on permissible outward remittances of savings by resident foreign nationals without special approval. In Sri Lanka inward remittances of foreign exchange proceeds from invisibles in excess of a specified amount were made subject to prior approval. With effect from December, Trinidad and Tobago required commer- cial banks to obtain prior approval for outward remittances of gifts and donations. In Yugoslavia trade in foreign currencies, checks, and letters of credit between residents and nonresidents was prohibited. Zambia announced that the commuted value of pensions for expatriate workers eligible for remittances was subject to a maximum limit and approval by the Bank of Zambia. In addition, the facility whereby gratuities of holders of certain forms of resident permit were remittable at the completion of a contract was canceled and gratuities could be remitted only at the time that the applicant was emigrating from Zambia. Remit- tances by residents to nonresidents for gift purposes were made subject to the approval of the Reserve Bank in Zimbabwe, although the maximum limits on the remittances remained unchanged. Several countries changed (mainly liberalized) regulations governing the export and import of domestic and foreign currency notes. Cyprus raised the limit on foreign currency notes that could be taken out of the country. Malaysia removed the limits on the import and export of currency notes by travelers.
