In addition, Chile announced that central bank authorization is re- quired for a number of current invisible transactions. Payments Arrears Payments arrears occur when the authorities of a country are responsible for undue delays, beyond those required by normal administrative proce- dures, in approving applications or in meeting bona fide requests for foreign exchange. Payments ar- rears constitute an exchange restriction under Arti- cle VIII, Section 2(a) when they involve current international transactions as described in Arti- cle XXX, Section (d) of the Fund's Articles of Agreement, and are therefore subject to approval under Article VIII. When payments arrears are incurred by the government because a country belonging to a common central bank arrangement is unable to obtain domestic currency with which to purchase needed foreign exchange from the com- mon central bank (Bank of Central African States (BEAC), Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO), and East Caribbean Currency Authority (ECCA)), such arrears are treated as government defaults rather than exchange restrictions. Pay- ments arrears incurred by a government itself are also treated as defaults. These distinctions between payments arrears and defaults are relevant, how- ever, only for the purpose of the Fund's jurisdiction under Article VIII; under the Fund's policy on the use of its resources, defaults as well as payments arrears on capital transfers and current payments are examined, and their orderly reduction and elimina- tion is usually made a performance criterion. In March 1982, and again in January 1983, the Fund reviewed the implementation of its policies with respect to payment arrears, steps taken by members to deal with arrears, and general devel- opments in this area. The major conclusions of these studies can be summarized as follows: (1) External payments arrears and defaults are incurred, generally speaking, when other measures to correct an unsustainable balance of payments position have not been adopted soon enough, or are of insufficient strength. Other possible measures aimed at keeping payments current include the imposition of exchange and trade restrictions and the rescheduling of the obligations as temporary expedients, while additional adjustment measures are brought to bear. The problems posed by external payments arrears have intensified sharply in 1982. Not only have aggregate arrears more than doubled in a short period, but there has been an increasing tendency for relatively more developed economies in Eastern Europe and Latin America to incur arrears. An increase in arrears raises the riskiness of international lending. One consequence is that countries in arrears are accorded reduced access to international capital markets. A second consequence is that the cost of international credit, as well as of imported goods and services, becomes higher than would otherwise be the case for most borrowers. (2) Performance criteria for the elimination or substantial reduction of external payments arrears constitute an important element of programs in support of the use of the Fund's resources. Being directed toward the normalization of creditor rela- tions and thus "unlocking" credits, Fund resources, supported by adjustment programs, play an impor- tant role in restoring the member's access to international credits at a sustainable level of real resource inflows. Where there is no program in effect with the Fund, the incurrence of arrears and related policies have been subject to careful scrutiny in the context of Article IV consultations with the Fund. In many instances, a requirement that the domestic currency counterpart of the arrears be deposited with the banking system not only will demonstrate the authorities' determination to re- duce and eventually eliminate payments arrears, but also will facilitate the monitoring of payments arrears, as well as their reduction in an orderly manner. In this connection, it may be noted that a number of programs in association with existing stand-by arrangements or the extended Fund facility provide for the counterpart deposit requirement. (3) In view of the disorderly nature of this form 37 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTRICTIONS of exchange restriction which makes it particularly undesirable, the Fund has consistently followed the practice of not approving the maintenance of arrears with respect to current international payments under Article VIII of the Fund's Articles, except when a satisfactory program for their elimination has been in place. Such a program is often associated with the use of Fund resources by the member, or in other instances the schedule for elimination may be incorporated in the framework of policy discussions with the member at the time of its Article IV consultation with the Fund. (4) The Fund has been continuing its efforts to aid in improving the quality of the data on payments arrears incurred by member countries, and some improvements have been evident. However, in a number of countries the quality of data relating to payments arrears is still deficient with respect to the total amount and the type of payments arrears. Moreover, the data on external payments arrears are available for most countries on a lagged basis on ly. If programs for the reduction of payments arrears are to contribute to a country's balance of payments and adjustment process, they must be coordinated with external debt and reserve managemen t. Pay- ments arrears involve continuous flows of exchange transactions, so that their restrict!veness may change frequently. According to the latest information available, the total of payments arrears (including those in respect of capital transactions) incurred by Fund members and government defaults is estimated to have amounted to SDR 13.5 billion at the end of 1982, more than double the amount of SDR 6.1 billion recorded at the end of 1981.17 During 1977-81 the total payments arrears of members had remained relatively constant. The record indicates that arrears, once ac- cumulated, tend to persist for several years. In some cases, the initial accumulations are so large that their liquidation presents severe problems. The number of countries incurring arrears has been rising almost continuously; of the 44 countries incurring arrears during 1975-82, only 8 countries have managed to eliminate them. Of the remaining countries, 10 experienced virtually continuously 17 The amounts of payments arrears and government defaults reported here are based on official national sources, compiled in some instances with the assistance of Fund staff or creditor organizations. This persistent and, to a certain degree, self- perpetuating nature of arrears underlines for mem- ber countries the importance of policies aimed at avoiding their initial incurrence. The number of countries incurring, or believed to be incurring, payments arrears and government defaults at the end of 1982 was 35, the same as at the end of 1981. Twenty-nine countries identified as having pay- ments arrears or government defaults, and for which information for the latter part of 1982 or the end of 1982 is available, are Argentina, Bolivia, Central African Republic, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, The Gambia, Ghana, Guatemala, Guinea, Guyana, Haiti, Hon- duras, Liberia, Madagascar, Mali, Mexico, Nicara- gua, Romania, Sierra Leone, Sudan, Tanzania, Togo, Uganda, Viet Nam, Western Samoa, Zaire, and Zambia. The global estimate of the outstanding payments arrears and government defaults at the end of 1982, therefore, includes the data for the end of 1981 of these countries (and, in two instances, the end of 1980). During 1982 payments arrears emerged in Argentina, Ecuador, Guatemala, and Mexico. Nigeria is known to have incurred payments ar- rears, but quantitative information is not available. Hungary incurred payments arrears but eliminated them before the end of the year. Five countries— the People's Republic of the Congo, Jamaica, Senegal, Somalia, and Turkey—eliminated their payments arrears or government defaults. During 1982, of the countries that had payments arrears or government defaults at the end of 1981, the outstanding amount rose in 19 countries (Bolivia, Central African Republic, Costa Rica, Domini- can Republic, Ghana, Guyana, Haiti, Honduras, Liberia, Madagascar, Romania, Sierra Leone, Su- dan, Tanzania, Togo, Viet Nam, Western Samoa, Zaire, and Zambia) and declined in 6 countries (El Salvador, The Gambia, Guinea, Mali, Nicaragua, and Uganda). In one country (Comoros) the out- standing amount remained unchanged. In part, the exceptionally high aggregate level of arrears as of last quarter of 1982 may be viewed as transitional. For a number of countries, rescheduling exercises are presently under way. However, the reschedul- ing would help in achieving a more sustainable balance of payments, when there is an inappropriate bunch ing of ma tu r i t ies and when ad ju s tment pro- grams are introduced aimed at generating the necessary strengthening of the overall balance of payments. Viewed from the perspective of total delays and deferments, the risk situation has not deteriorated quite as markedly as the more than doubling of arrears noted above would suggest. Multiple Currency Practices Article VIII, Section 3 of the Fund's Articles of Agreement prohibits a member from engaging in, or permitting its fiscal agencies to engage in, any discriminatory currency arrangements or multiple currency practices without the approval of the Fund.20 Such practices encompass separate ex- change rates (through the mechanism of dual or multiple exchange markets, the establishment of separate official exchange rates for specified trans- actions, or the application of exchange measures, including exchange taxes or subsidies, and exces- sive exchange rate spreads), broken cross rates, or discriminatory currency arrangements. During 1982, as in 1981 and 1980, about one third of the Fund's members engaged in multiple currency practices.21 Few of the multiple currency practices (involving eight members) remained unapproved by the Fund following consultations with members concluded in 1982 and early 1983. The longer-run trend toward a decreased inci- dence of multiple currency practices among Fund members resumed in 1982, following a leveling-off in 1981. Five members eliminated all remaining multiple currency practices during 1982,22 whereas in 1981 no member eliminated all practices. Of the 45 members maintaining multiple currency prac- tices at the end of December 1982, 9 countries made changes in their multiple currency practices during the period under review that resulted in a net simplification, including 3 that eliminated a spe- 20 For a detailed description of the October 1979 and March 1981 reviews of the concept of, and Fund policies relating to, multiple currency practices and the criteria applied by the Fund in determining the existence of multiple currency practices and broken cross rates, see the Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions, 1980, page 17, and 1981, pages 22-23. 21 In this section all forms of multiple currency practices, that is, multiple currency practices involving capital as well as current transactions, are discussed. 22Lao People's Democratic Republic, Maldives, Mauritius, Somalia, and Turkey. During 1982, three countries eliminated some multiple currency practices, but not all. Argentina reunified its exchange market in November, after splitting it into a commercial and a f inanc ial market in Ju ly, and introduced a mixing rate for trade transactions in September, calculated as a percent- age of the commercial and financial market. The only remaining mu l t ip le currency practice in Argentina is the system of tax rebates for promoted exports, for which the rates were changed from 10 percent to 5, 10, and 14 percent, respectively, in 1982. Ecuador modified the operation of its ex- change system under which three sets of exchange rates existed: the fixed official rate, the nonofficial free market rate, and the free market rate of the Central Bank. In March Ecuador shifted tourist receipts arid a large part of trade transactions from the central bank free market to the official market. In May, following the devaluation of the sucre in the official market, Ecuador abolished the central bank free market leaving two markets in effec t. Romania continued the simplification of its ex- change system. In January exchange rates d ifferent from the commercial rate of lei 15 = US$1 that are applicable to exports were reduced from 25 to 12, as was the spread between the highest and lowest rates, from lei 17 = US$1 to lei 10 = US$1. Since May 1982, Algerian workers are required to change F 700 at the official exchange rate and are given the pre- mium only for amounts above this level. Brazil made several modifications in its mu l t ip le currency practices. A number of imports, inc lud ing soy- beans, raw hides, and leather, were effectively exempted from the tax on financial operations (IOF), while the export taxes on cattle hides and orange and tangerine ju ice were lowered. In addi- tion, the graduated supplementary income tax of 40 percent to 60 percent on remittances of dividends from investment companies that exceed 12 percent a year of invested capital was abolished in Decem- ber. In September Colombia reduced the taxes applied to foreign exchange proceeds from 12 percent to 9 percent. Costa Rica officially recog- nized the free exchange market in August by authorizing banks to handle all exchange transac- tions, including those previously handled by the exchange houses, in the free market. Three ex- change markets remain in effect: (1) the official market, (2) the banking market, and (3) the free market. A mixing rate also results from the require- ment that foreign exchange proceeds of exports be surrendered: 5 percent at the official exchange rate and 95 percent at the banking rate, compared with 10 percent and 90 percent, respectively, at the end of 1981. In the early fa l l, the Dominican Republic recognized the parallel exchange market by authorizing the commercial banks to participate in that market. In conformity with an adjustment program supported by the Fund, El Salvador shifted the following transactions from the official market to the parallel market: proceeds from exports of specified nontraditional products to countries out- side Central America, inc lud ing those from indus- tries which export more than 25 percent of their products to these countries; specified incomes and receipts from tourism and diplomats; and author- ized imports. In accordance with its obligation under the Accession Treaty with the EC, Greece reduced the rates for advance import deposits for specified imports by a third, to one half of the levels prevailing before January 1, 1981. Actions creating new multiple currency practices or modifying multiple currency practices in such a way as to result in a net intensification were taken in 15 countries in 1982. As previously mentioned, both Argentina and Bolivia adopted dual exchange markets which were unified later in the year. Brazil expanded its list of exports eligible for tax credits in 1982 to include a variety of additional products. Furthermore, the general export tax credit of 11 percent, which was to be lowered to 9 percent on December 31, and eliminated by March 31, 1983, was extended until April 30, 1985. Additional taxes on specified manufactured exports to the United States were established to prevent the imposition of countervailing duties by the United States. With effect from September 3, the Central Bank of Chile sold foreign exchange at a preferential rate —fixed at Ch$49.623 = US$1 on August 6—for the servicing of foreign debt obligations and debt denominated or guaranteed in foreign exchange and contracted prior to August 6, 1982, while all other transactions continued to be effected at the official rate. Colombia increased the rates of tax credit certificates granted to certain exports from the rates of 5 percent, 9 percent, and 12 percent to 5 percent, 10 percent, and 15 percent, respectively. In the context of an overall adjustment program that was formally adopted in December, Guinea formally recognized a system under which the application of the official exchange rate of GS 24.6853 = SDR 1 is limited to exchange transactions effected through the official channel; all other transactions are channeled through the unofficial parallel market. Mexico introduced a dual exchange market system in 1982 and modified it several times during the year. In August Mexico established a dual ex- change market consisting of a preferential rate— which applied mainly to certain priority imports, sales of exchange for servicing public sector debt, interest payments for private sector debt, public 42 sector foreign borrowing, and proceeds from petro- leum exports—and a freely floating rate at which commercial banks were authorized to buy and sell foreign exchange for all other transactions. On September 1 a generalized foreign exchange control system was announced in which two basic ex- change rates were maintained—an ordinary rate of Mex$70 = US$1 and a preferential rate of Mex$50 = US$1. Sales of foreign exchange at the preferen- tial rate were to apply principally to debt of domestic credit institutions and the public sector, to principal and interest payments for private sector obligations entered into prior to September 1, and to a broad spectrum of officially authorized im- ports. On October 29 the authorities announced the establishment of a third exchange market in the border areas and free trade zones in which the exchange rate was to be determined by supply and demand. In December, the Mexican authorities revoked the generalized exchange control system and established two foreign exchange markets: a controlled and a free market. The controlled market rate, adjusted on a daily basis, involves the follow- ing specific transactions: (1) all merchandise export receipts, (2) public and private sector principal and interest payments, (3) specified imports, (4) Mexi- can payments to international organizations, and (5) other authorized transactions. All other transactions are effected in the free market at a rate determined by supply and demand, except for the repayment of certain obligations by financial institutions and leasing companies which is effected at a special rate set at Mex$50 = US$1. Nicaragua adopted several multiple currency practices in addition to the previously existing dual exchange market consist- ing of an official market, in which the rate is pegged to the U.S. dollar, and a parallel market, in which the rate is floating but subject to official intervention. Effective February 15 a tax of C$5 = US$1 was introduced on purchases of foreign exchange in the official market for payments of nonessential imports; at the same time, export taxes on several agricultural products were lowered. In March several different effective exchange rates emerged from new regulations that required a specified portion of the f .o .b. proceeds of certain merchandise exports to be surrendered in return for exchange certificates and the rest to be exchanged at various mixing proportions through the official and parallel markets. In April Nigeria introduced a non-interest-bearing advance import deposit re- quirement, ranging from 25 percent to 250 percent. Uganda introduced a dual exchange market system in August which includes a market ("Win- dow One") in which foreign exchange is allocated at a preferential rate managed by the Bank of Uganda for specified transactions such as certain imports, public debt service payments, loans and grants, and traditional agricultural exports. In the second market ("Window Two") limited amounts of foreign exchange are sold for all payments not eligible for financing at Window One in a weekly auction administered by the Bank of Uganda. In Zambia a 10 percent levy was imposed in February on the sale of foreign exchange for travel abroad. Two countries, Egypt and Indonesia, made changes to their multiple currency practices that did not substantially alter their pre-existing ar- rangements. In March Egypt announced that all private sector imports passing through, but not directly involving, commercial banks were to be financed through the "own exchange market" at fluctuating rates freely determined by buyer and seller. In addition, advance import deposits were to be made in foreign exchange instead of in either Egyptian pounds or foreign exchange. Both mea- sures essentially meant a return to the system prevailing prior to August 1, 1981. In April Indonesia introduced new procedures for collecting the export tax and the additional export tax. As a result of the modification, the taxes now give rise to multiple currency practices. In January 1983, Jamaica introduced a dual exchange market, under which settlements in respect of traditional exports, exports to CARICOM countries, specified invisibles, and essential imports would be effected at the official exchange rate; all other transactions would be conducted in a parallel market, operated by the commercial banks, at a freely determined exchange rate. On the first day of trading, January 10, the parallel market rate was approximately J$2.50 = US$1.00, representing a 29 percent devaluation relative to the official rate. Major changes in members' multiple currency practices in early 1983 included liberalization of existing practices by three members. In March Brazil eliminated the financial transactions tax (IOF) applied to purchases of foreign exchange for travel expenses, unworked coal, sodium carbonate and reduced it by 40 percent for a specific list of commodity imports. Export taxes on several prod- ucts were also reduced at that time and were to be further reduced at a later date. In addition to a devaluation of the sucre and the introduction of a preannounced daily depreciation of the official exchange rate in February, Ecuador limited the transactions to be effected at the official rate to the following: (a) payments for the c. & f. value of certain imports; (b) specific debt service payments and public sector expenditures; and (c) specified expenses for invisibles. In addition, 70 percent— instead of the previous 100 percent—of proceeds from certain exports were required to be surren- dered in the official market. All other transactions were to be channeled through the free market. In February 1983 South Africa announced the abolish- ment of exchange control over nonresidents that resulted in the unification of the dual exchange rate system that had existed in one form or another since exchange control affecting nonresidents was first introduced in South Africa. In March Rwanda adopted an advance import deposit scheme under which pur- chases of foreign exchange would be subject to the requirement of a non-interest-bearing deposit for nine months, equivalent to 100 percent or 50 percent of the value of the import. Venezuela adopted a three-tier exchange market system in March consisting of two fixed rates, Bs 4.30 = US$1 and Bs 6.0 = US$1, for specified transac- tions and a managed floating rate for tourism, private transfers, and capital flows. Bilateral Payments Arrangements Bilateral payments arrangements maintained be- tween Fund members constitute restrictions under Article VIII of the Fund's Articles of Agreement to the extent that they involve exchange restrictions or multiple currency practices. A basic feature of bilateral payments arrangements, which gives rise to a restriction on the making of payments and transfers for current international transactions, is that balances in the bilateral account, which is typically established to settle bilateral trade transac- tions, can be used only to make settlements be- tween the two partner countries and cannot be transferred into another currency or be used to make payments to a third country. Even where the transferability of balances in the bilateral account is allowed, an exchange restriction within the mean- ing of Article VIII, Section 2(a) may be involved if the period between transfers is undu ly long. A discriminatory currency arrangement within the ambit of Article VIII, Section 3 of the Fund's Articles may also be involved if credit balances in the bilateral account are not remunerated at the prevailing representative interest rate or if transfers of balances are made at exchange rates whose cross rate differentials exceed more than 1 percent. In September 1982 the Executive Board re- viewed the Fund's policy with respect to bilateral payments arrangements and the use of countertrade arrangements. The broad conclusions of this review were the following: (1) During the period 1976^81 further progress was made by Fund members in reducing their reliance on bilateral payments arrangements, as measured by the number of bilateral payments arrangements in force, by the total number of Fund members maintaining bilateral payments agree- ments, and by the estimated proportion of trade 44 conducted under such arrangements.25 The elimi- nation of bilateral payments agreements of Fund members with countries having centrally planned economies (including Fund members) has been somewhat slower. (2) The Fund's policy of not approving the maintenance of bilateral payments agreements and of encouraging their termination in the context of Article IV consultations has contributed to a decline in the use of bilateral payments arrangements. The approach set out in Executive Board Decision No. 955(59/45), adopted on October 23, 1959, remains appropriate; that is, that (a) there is no justification on balance of payments grounds for discrimination by members whose current receipts are largely in externally convertible currencies, (b) where such discriminatory restrictions have long been maintained, a reasonable amount of time may be needed to eliminate them, but this time should be short, and (c) in the case of payments relations with countries having centrally planned economies in which limitations exist on convertibility, the Fund would be prepared to consider whether balance of payments considerations would ju s t i fy the mainte- nance of some degree of discrimination. The number of members continuing to maintain bilateral payments arrangements at present suggests that the policy in (b) should continue to be implemented rigorously. (3) The Fund's policy on bilateral payments arrangements maintained between Fund members in the context of the use of its resources will be continued. Intentions with respect to bilateral pay- ments arrangements that are inconsistent with Arti- cle VIII will continue to be a performance criterion under upper credit tranche stand-by and extended arrangements of the Fund. Close attention will be paid to bilateral payments agreements maintained by Fund members that have concluded successive stand-by or extended arrangements, and these will be examined to ascertain whether or not balance of payments considerations jus t i fy more rapid prog- ress toward elimination of these arrangements in the context of subsequent programs supported by the member's use of Fund resources. 25 At the end of 1981, despite the increase in membership, 41 Fund members maintained one or more bilateral payments arrangements, compared with 56 at the end of 1975—the date of the previous review by the Fund. The total number of bilateral payments arrangements maintained by Fund members also declined over this period, to 149 from 220. Exports by Fund members to countries with which they have bilateral payments agreements are estimated to have fallen from 8.5 percent of total world exports in 1954 to 2 percent in 1964, and to less than V* of 1 percent in 1980. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MA IN DEVELOPMENTS IN RESTRICTIVE PRACTICES (4) The Fund would continue to encourage members to terminate bilateral payments agree- ments that are inconsistent with Article VIII, including those that are maintained under the transitional provisions of Article XIV. Decisions by the Executive Board under Article VIII and Arti- cle XIV would continue to mention specifically such bilateral payments arrangements. As in the past this approach would apply to all members, including those with centrally planned economies. (5) The use of countertrade arrangements and their impact on the development of a multilateral system of trade and payments need to be kept under review. Should there be reason to believe that such arrangements are the cause of problems, the staff will, in the course of Article IV consultation discussions and discussions on the use of the Fund's resources, endeavor to collect relevant information and examine such practices as closely as possible in order to ascertain whether restrictive and dis- criminatory exchange measures subject to Arti- cle VIII are involved. The 1982 Annual Report on Exchange Ar- rangements and Exchange Restrictions noted that, during 1981, 4 bilateral payments agreements be- tween Fund members and 2 bilateral payments agreements between Fund members and non-Fund members were terminated, while a new agreement between a Fund member and a non-Fund member was concluded. At the beginning of 1982, bilateral payments agreements maintained between Fund members totaled 51, and the total number of bilateral payments agreements maintained between Fund members and non-Fund members was 98. There was a further decline in the number of bilateral payments agreements (including inopera- tive agreements) maintained between Fund mem- bers and between Fund members and non-Fund members in 1982. In March the People's Republic of China and the Syrian Arab Republic agreed to place payments on a convertible currency basis, with effect from January 1, 1983. The People's Republic of China also signed an agreement with Finland in June to terminate the bilateral payments agreement by the end of 1982. In June, Colombia terminated the bilateral payments agreement with Yugoslavia. In May, the inoperative bilateral pay- ments agreement between Egypt and Jordan was terminated. In March, Lebanon and Romania con- cluded an agreement to effect all payments in convertible currencies, and un t il the agreement is ratified by the two governments, all payments are being settled in convertible currencies. Several Fund members terminated bilateral payments agree- ments maintained with non-Fund members; these were between Morocco and the U .S .S .R ., Peru and Poland, Turkey and Albania, and Turkey and the U .S .S .R. During 1982 three bilateral payments agreements were concluded between Fund members. In April agreements were concluded between the Islamic Republic of Iran and Pakistan and between the Islamic Republic of Iran and the Syrian Arab Republic and in June also between the Islamic Republic of Iran and Turkey. At the time of joining the Fund on May 6, 1982, Hungary was maintain- ing 14 bilateral payments agreements—12 with Fund members and 2 with non-Fund members. Excluding the effect of Hungary's membership, the bilateral payments agreements maintained between Fund members at the end of 1982 totaled 50, and those maintained between Fund members and non- Fund members numbered 94. If the bilateral pay- ments agreements maintained by Hungary were to be included, the total number of agreements main- tained by Fund members would be 62, and the total number of agreements maintained between Fund members and non-Fund members would be 84. The decline in the reliance on bilateral payments agreements by Fund members since the mid-1970s has also been reflected in the number of agreements maintained by each member during 1976-82. Be- tween 1976 and 1982, the number of Fund mem- bers maintaining between 1 and 5 agreements remained unchanged at 23, whereas the number of Fund members maintaining between 6 and 9 agree- ments declined from 14 to 2, and the number of Fund members maintaining more than 9 agreements declined from 7 to 3 (including Hungary). Detailed information on the value of trade con- ducted under bilateral payments agreements is not available for most Fund members maintaining such arrangements. On the assumption that the value of trade between Fund members maintaining bilateral payments agreements represents the max imum value of trade conducted under bilateral payments arrangements, the total value of such trade was equivalent to just under 1A of 1 percent of the value of world trade of Fund members in 1980. It is most likely that the value of trade conducted under bilateral payments arrangements is considerably smaller than the above ratio suggests, because all trade between Fund members maintaining bilateral payments arrangements is not usually settled under the arrangements; in many instances, only the trade of a group of products specified in a trade agree- ment is settled under bilateral payments ar- rangements. A further refinement would be to make 45 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON EXCHANGE ARRANGEMENTS AND EXCHANGE RESTR ICT IONS an assessment of the trade-creating or trade- diverting effects on third countries. Such a calcula- tion is not possible in view of the paucity of data. In recent years, countertrade arrangements have become an increasingly important form of bilateral- ism.26 Countertrade refers to bilateral trading ar- rangements between foreign trade organizations or private firms in the exporting and importing coun- try, under which the seller is obligated to purchase, as a partial or total settlement for his merchandise exports, or in some instances sales of services in the form of technology and industrial licenses, specified goods or services from the importing country on a barter basis or during a specified period. Countertrade is generally motivated by the desire to economize on the use of convertible foreign exchange, to improve access to markets and maintain market shares, and to take advantage of credit facilities that may be available. Reliable estimates of trade conducted under countertrade arrangements are not often available because such arrangements are most often engaged in by ind i- vidual firms without the knowledge of the govern- ment, or in instances where governments engage in such arrangements and strategic goods are in- volved, trade data are not published. In some instances, the period of countertrade arrangements extends over several years so that estimation of the value of annual trade flows is also d i f f icu l t. Although countertrade arrangements may fa ll outside the Fund's jurisdiction if exchange restric- tions imposed by either of the respective national authorities are not involved, or are not otherwise subject to policies accompanying use of the Fund 's resources, the Fund is generally concerned w i th 26 The OECD has estimated that up to 15-20 percent of the trade between the East European and the West European countries is conducted under some form of countertrade arrangements. According to the Fund's Direction of Trade Statistics, Western industrial countries' exports to and imports from the East European countries in 1980 totaled US$80 billion. On the basis of the OECD estimate, the level of countertrade in East-West trade in 1980 would therefore have amounted to a maximum of some US$12-16 billion. In a recent study by the U.S. International Trade Commission, U .S. imports resulting from countertrade arrangements were es- timated to be US$279 million in 1980, of which about US$170 million were estimated to have been from the centrally planned economies. This study also concluded that the value of countertrade exports in most instances exceeded the value of countertrade imports since only a portion of the value of total U.S. countertrade exports is paid for w i th countertrade im- ports. Assuming the share of U.S. countertrade w i th devel- oping countries to be representative of other industrial coun- tries, global countertrade may be roughly estimated to be about 1 percent of world trade. This is larger than the estimated value of trade conducted under bilateral payments arrangements noted above. 46 their proliferation because they may be seen as undermining the objective of the multilateral trad- ing system, the promotion of wh ich was a basic objective for the setting up of the Fund, and also because they share many of the microeconomic disadvantages that are common in bilateral pay- ments arrangements. Based on recent experience, some of the more common and serious disadvan- tages generally encountered in countertrade ar- rangements are (1) a limited choice of products or services that are available for trading at internation- ally competitive prices; (2) poor qua l i ty of goods; (3) the d iff icu l ty of marketing products that are not directly consumed by the buyer, especially when the seller places geographical or commercial re- strictions on the marketing of products; and (4) a higher product cost resulting from payments of commissions or fees to the middleman handling sales of products and from bridge financing that may be required owing to long delivery dates. Capital Flows In the postwar period there has been a gradual liberalization of international capital f lows, a trend that accelerated during the 1970s w i th the move toward more flexible exchange rate arrangements and the need to redistribute oil surpluses. While this enhanced freedom and mobility of capital move- ments has had clear economic advantages, it has also led to an increased sensitivity of funds to interest rate differentials and exchange rate expecta- tions. As a result, the emergence du r ing the recent past of significant real interest rate spreads among major financial markets has, along with rapidly changing exchange rate expectations, emphasized the interdependence of economic policy manage- ment. Continuing balance of payments d i f f icu l t ies in certain countries, especially developing coun- tries, have led to imposition of capital restrictions as part of a general reversion to exchange controls in these countries in recent years. There were several changes during the period under review relating to the international operations of banks in industrial countries. On balance, these actions served to facilitate the international mobility of capital. In January the National Bank of Austria renewed the regulation that foreign currency credits extended by domestic banks to nonresidents could not be higher than repayments in addition to 15 percent of corresponding credits outstanding at the end of 1981. In February the Belgium-Luxembourg Exchange Institute decreed that prior to March 22 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MA IN DEVELOPMENTS IN RESTR ICT IVE PRACTICES all foreign exchange holdings in "regulated" ac- counts had to be either used or sold at the official exchange rate and, fur ther, that term deposits in these accounts beyond March 22 were no longer permitted. Rules governing "regulated" accounts were somewhat altered in April, to the effect that liquidation of these deposits would take place at the official exchange rate, w i th all exchange rate gains accruing to the Treasury, and that term deposits of up to one month were permitted provided that the owner of the account had no outstanding exchange obligations in the official market fa l l ing due during the term of the deposit. In June it was announced that with immediate effect diplomatic and interna- tional staff in Belgium could, subject to m in imal conditions, again deposit their salaries in a special convertible account. The ECU operations of com- mercial banks in France were simplified in May by the decision that the ECU, including its French franc component, was to be treated as a foreign currency. In January Japan announced a scheme whereby the Ministry of Finance would provide, from its foreign exchange fund special account, U .S. dollar financing for emergency imports judged to be conducive to an easing of trade fr ic t ions, up to a total of US$500 m i l l ion. In April the Ministry increased, as a result of its regular review, yen- dollar swap limits for foreign banks operating in Japan, and in May priority categories for long-term overseas yen lending by banks were removed. Under revised bank rules, Japanese banks could, after June, open two additional overseas branch offices in the two fiscal years 1981/82 and 1982/83. In January Sweden permitted funds deposited in foreign exchange accounts to be placed in interest- bearing accounts with other authorized banks. Switzerland, with effect from October 28 permitted foreign banks to take up subparticipations in Swiss franc bond issues and in U .S. dollar bond issues with ("dual currency bonds") or w i thout a Swiss franc link. Measures taken by industrial countries in the area of portfolio investment tended to liberalize inflows and to restrict outflows. Among the liberalizing measures, with effect from January 1983, Japan altered procedures for the issuance of yen- denominated bonds, subs t i tu t ing a quarterly is- suance program for an annual queu ing system. The Netherlands in early January abolished a regulation stipulating that without specific licenses residents would not be permitted to purchase unlisted foreign fixed-interest securities that were denominated in guilders at the time of placement. In February Norway abolished the limit of NKr 1 m i l l ion on purchases of Norwegian quoted shares by nonresi- dents. In April Switzerland, in permitting the placement of a bond issue by the World Bank, departed from existing regulations in that it offered an exchange guarantee; the bonds had a maturity of seven years rather than the officially required minimum of nine years; it permitted foreign banks to be underwriters; and the bonds were listed on both the London and Swiss exchanges. In Ju ly Switzerland further relaxed restrictions on the placement and trading of medium-term negotiable paper. The limit beyond which the placement of notes would require authorization from the National Bank was raised, the m in imum maturity for both foreign Swiss franc bond other negotiable paper issues was lowered and conditions for advance repayment of notes were relaxed. Among the limited number of restrictive mea- sures taken by industrial countries with respect to portfolio investment, in February the Bank of Norway set an upper limit on short-term borrowing abroad, by most Norwegian commercial enterprises in 1982. In August Spain temporarily suspended a 1979 decree liberalizing portfolio investment abroad, announcing that for a period of six months prior authorization would be required to transfer funds abroad for foreign portfolio investment. During 1982 the limited number of actions taken by industrial countries in the area of direct invest- ment were, in the main, towards liberalization. In June Canada announced that the administrative procedures of the Foreign Investment Review Act (FIRA) would be simplified in various ways. In Ju ly Denmark raised the limit beyond which indi- vidual transactions and remittances would be sub- ject to exchange regulations and increased limits applicable to both outward and inward direct investment. In conjunction with measures that made it more d iff icu lt for individuals to gain nonresident status and to transfer capital abroad, France in March required that all direct investment in excess of F 1 million be financed abroad. In August Italy required Italian companies to obtain prior approval to set up an overseas financial holding. The decree also established notification requirements for any participation exceeding 10 percent by a resident in a foreign holding company. The Netherlands in January discontinued the re- quirement that no net capital importation should result from financial guarantees for borrowings by nonresidents. In October Greece required that foreign exchange sold for transfer abroad on behalf of nationals working overseas be recorded in the passport of the recipient. A number of developing countries took measures relating to portfolio and direct investments. In April Argentina announced that amortization and interest payments with respect to foreign debt could not be made more than two days prior to the due date and suspended the right to transfer profits and to repatriate investments. Foreign obligations arising from profits, dividends, royalties, and technical assistance were required to be paid with U .S. dollar-denominated bonds (BONEX) issued by the Government of Argentina. In April the Central Bank of Argentina also announced that no external payment commitment could be entered into without its prior consent. In May the Central Bank resumed swap operations with the private sector that had been suspended since late December 1981, and in July the Central Bank announced that it would undertake swaps against loan proceeds surrendered in the financial market after July 6. In December the requirement was introduced that these swaps on maturity had to be rolled over for a period of at least 90 days and had to carry a guaranteed exchange rate, a maximum maturity period of 180 days, and a maximum charge of 6 percent a month. In July the Central Bank introduced an exchange rate guaran- tee scheme for financial loans negotiated prior to July 6. To be eligible for this guarantee, the debtor had to secure an extension of the maturity of the loan for at least one year. Loans covered under previous guarantee schemes could, upon maturity, be brought under the new scheme provided that a further extension of its maturity for a minimum of one year was obtained. In mid-July the scheme was extended to cover import payments contracted before July 2 provided that the importer secured a new loan for an equivalent amount; concurrently the scheme was extended to trade financing re- lated to imports and to interest payments accruing through December 31 on loans carrying an ex- change rate guarantee. In August payment of interest on foreign loans that had accrued through July 2 and for which an exchange application was pending on that date was permitted without prior authorization from the Central Bank, provided that the debtor obtained an extension of maturity for at least one year. Principal payments on foreign loans for which an exchange application was pending on July 2 could still be effected through the purchase of BONEX bonds provided that the counterpart in pesos was paid to an authorized agency by August 6; otherwise such principal payments could be made only at the current exchange rate and would require the prior authorization of the Central Bank. On November 17 the Central Bank required that all external loans carrying an exchange rate guarantee issued by the Central Bank during 1981 be rescheduled and established the minimum terms for that rescheduling. Interest on these loans contin- ued to be fu l ly transferable. The rescheduling requirements did not apply in cases where the domestic borrower had, by October 22, obtained a voluntary extension of the loan and a new exchange rate guarantee under the scheme established in July. In November payments of amortization with respect to private sector foreign borrowing were made subject to prior central bank approval, although the automaticity of transfers of interest payments was retained; previously all such payments could be effected automatically. In August Algeria relaxed regulations concerning repatriation of earnings and royalties of joint ventures. In late December Brazil announced that a tax credit had been introduced for nonresidents converting their loans into invest- ments. The committees noted that, in all countries, the agreements were in general operating satisfactorily. Individual areas of improvement were also discussed. The EC-Romania joint committee met on De- cember 2-3 to review the operations of the 1980 trade agreement. The two parties decided to start discussions at expert level of a more comprehensive agreement on economic cooperation. Simulta- neously, discussions would be held on expanding the number of items included under the present trade agreement. A framework agreement for cooperation between the EC and Brazil entered into effect on October 1. The agreement, which had a five-year initial dura- tion, replaced the 1974 trade agreement and aims at providing a more stable institutional context to the relationship between the two parties. It was de- signed to encourage the expansion of commercial cooperation in general between the two parties and to develop economic cooperation through a joint committee established for this purpose. Representatives of the EC and the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN)29 met on various occasions during the year to discuss prog- ress made in cooperation projects undertaken under the aegis of their cooperation agreement signed in 1980. At the meeting of the EC-China joint com- mittee on November 11-12, the two parties noted consensus on renewing the current agreement that was to expire on May 31, 1983. A widening of the scope of the agreement for 1982 by the inclusion of some ten new products in the liberalization list and increases in a number of quotas was also announced at the meeting. The annual summit conference of the Economic Community of West African States (EcowAS)30 was held in Cotonou, Benin, during May 28-29, 1982. For technical reasons, this was not approved, thus further postponing the lifting of all tariffs on intracommu- nity trade in goods from community enterprises, which was to have taken effect on May 28, 1981. The heads of state approved the creation of an Energy Resources Development Fund within the ECOWAS Fund, to which member states would contribute voluntarily. The heads of state of the WAEC met in Yamous- soukro, Ivory Coast, in late December. The discus- sions centered on efforts to satisfy the needs of the populations of member countries for water re- sources, mass transport systems, and health and education. On the same occasion, the heads of state of the West African Monetary Union (WAMU)32 met to discuss issues of common interest. The final communique indicated that work progressed on a regional strategy toward the improvement of finan- cial and economic conditions of the member coun- tries. The African and Mauritian Common Organiza- tion (AMCO)33 also convened a summit meeting in Yamoussoukro in late December. The heads of state decided to continue their support of AMCO and to discuss its structure and objectives at the following meeting. The Senegambia Confederation, uniting Senegal with The Gambia, took effect on February 1. Both countries retain their sovereignty under the terms of the union, but will develop joint policies for defense, foreign affairs, finance, and customs. On July 2, the two Governments signed three protocols covering confederate institutions, financial regula- tions, and external relations policies. The South Pacific Forum37 held its thirteenth meeting in Rotorua, New Zealand, in August. On economic matters, the Forum affirmed the commit- ment to develop the fisheries resources of member states for the benefit of their people. At the meeting, the Federated States of Micronesia were made full members of the Forum Fisheries Agency. The question of establishing a Pacific Islands Fund for loans to island nations was postponed pending further study. During 1982, two countries, Vanuatu and Nauru, became signatories to the South Pacific Region- al Trade and Economic Cooperation Agreement (SPARTECA). SPARTECA, which entered into force on January 1, 1981, provides for nonreciprocal duty-free, unrestricted or concessional access to the markets of New Zealand and Australia for a wide range of products imported from signatory countries. Member countries of the ASEAN continued to expand the scope of their Preferential Trading Arrangement during 1982. In January, the number of items subject to the arrangement was increased to 8,529, with the addition of 1,948 new items. Moreover, the ceiling on annual import values of items which are subject to a 20-25 percent tariff cut was raised in steps from US$500,000 at the beginning of the year to US$10 million at the November meeting of the Ministers of Finance. At the November meeting, the Ministers of Finance also signed an agreement on ASEAN Industrial Joint Ventures. Products of industrial joint ventures are assured access to all ASEAN countries, and would be given substantial margins of tariff preference. The ministers also agreed to deepen the tariff cuts on nonfood items already under the preferential trading agreement, and on future exchanges, to a maximum of 50 percent. The ASEAN swap arrangement, which allows credit to be obtained by a member country facing temporary liquidity problems, was extended for another five years from February 1982. The heads of state of the members of the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC)38 held their second annual meeting in Bahrain on November 9. At the previous meeting in November 1981, a unified economic agreement, calling for unification and coordination of economic policies, had been ap- proved. According to this agreement, customs duties on intra-GCC trade in manufactured goods were to be abolished on December 1, 1982. At the November meeting, however, it was decided to postpone the elimination of customs duties until March 1983. The ministers approved the formation of a Gulf Organization for Investment (GOI), which would have a capital of US$2,100 million, with shares equally divided between the six member states. In the Latin American Integration Association (LAIA),39 which superseded the Latin American Free Trade Association (LAFTA) in 1980, progress was made in renegotiating the trade preferences originally negotiated under LAFTA. A high level meeting of government representatives in June reaffirmed the intention of the member countries to put the regional preferential arrangements into effect as soon as possible. At the meeting of the thirty-fourth Andean Pact Commission,40 held in Lima from March 17-19, agreement was reached on new rules for multina- tional Andean corporations. Such corporations would be required to have at least 80 percent Andean ownership.
